newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE white sugar recovers after NY-led selloff.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE white sugar recovers after NY-led selloff.

text.p: White sugar futures mimicked the sudden swings in the New York market but managed to claw their way back from the lows in late afternoon activity, traders said on Friday.
New York's March raws contract, which expires in a week's time, slumped to a low of 10.95 cents/lb on a combination of speculative and trade selling.
London stirred into life and followed the downward trend but bargain-hunters soon dragged the nearby values higher into mid-range, traders said.
"It's stabilised somewhat but the whites didn't really take a battering," said one trader.
"There's not a lot of conviction in London one way or the other, the speed was so quick."
At 1730 GMT May was down $2.00 at $309.00 after moving in a range between $307.40 and $311.00. August was down $1.30 at $309.00.
But volume stayed on the light side at 638 lots, showing that the swings on the whites market were a reaction to New York. Earlier trading was dominated by trade house crosses on May.
Light selling of the May/May arbitrage was noted at around $68 and the differential quickly narrowed to $66.
Market sources said the origins of the sugar purchased by Iran in its recent buying tender were the European Union for the whites and Cuba for the raws.
Confirmation of the sellers is still awaited but a leading London trade house was believed to be the seller of the whites while two other houses were involved in the raws deal, they said.
The Paris market also followed the general trend and lost ground. May was down $2.00 at $309.00 and August down $1.60 at $309.00.
Volume was concentrated in May and totalled 488 lots.
